articles.headline: Health Exchange Enrollment Jumps, Even as G.O.P. Pledges Repeal
articles.snippet: The Obama administration said 6.4 million people had signed up so far for 2017 health insurance, an increase of 400,000 over a similar point last year.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration said 6.4 million people had signed up so far for 2017 health insurance, an increase of 400,000 over a similar point last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 6.4 million people have signed up for health insurance next year under the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration said Wednesday, as people rushed to purchase plans regardless of Republican promises that the law will be repealed within months.

articles.headline: Calpers Cuts Investment Targets, Increasing Strain on Municipalities
articles.snippet: Its move is likely to prompt pension systems in other states to do the same while forcing California’s local governments, many with already troubled budgets, to pay more.
articles.abstract: Its move is likely to prompt pension systems in other states to do the same while forcing California’s local governments, many with already troubled budgets, to pay more.
articles.lead_paragraph: The board of California’s state public pension system, Calpers, voted Wednesday to lower expectations for future investment returns, a step that will increase pressure on the budgets of towns and cities across the state.

articles.headline: Secret Unit Helped Brazilian Company Bribe Government Officials
articles.snippet: U.S., Brazilian and Swiss prosecutors say Brazil’s Odebrecht paid hundreds of millions of dollars to officials in 12 countries in a scheme lasting two decades.
articles.abstract: U.S., Brazilian and Swiss prosecutors say Brazil’s Odebrecht paid hundreds of millions of dollars to officials in 12 countries in a scheme lasting two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Latin America’s biggest construction company, bribing government officials around the world became so common that a division was created devoted to tracking and facilitating kickbacks.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Vinod Sreeharsha

articles.headline: Trump Suggests Berlin Attack Affirms His Plan to Bar Muslims
articles.snippet: “All along, I’ve proven to be right,” the president-elect told reporters, speaking of the truck rampage that killed 12 and injured dozens.
articles.abstract: “All along, I’ve proven to be right,” the president-elect told reporters, speaking of the truck rampage that killed 12 and injured dozens.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump seemed to suggest on Wednesday that the deadly truck attack on a Christmas market in Berlin vindicated his proposal during the presidential campaign to bar Muslims from entering the United States.

articles.headline: Berlin Attack Sets Off Hunt for a Tunisian in Germany
articles.snippet: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials.
articles.abstract: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Searching the cab of the tractor-trailer that plowed through a Christmas market in Berlin, the authorities made two startling discoveries: a badly bruised body with stab and gunshot wounds, and the wallet of a Tunisian labeled a security threat who was supposed to have been deported months ago.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy, Jack Ewing, Joanna Berendt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Trump’s Son, Fearing ‘Quagmire,’ to Stop Soliciting for Charity
articles.snippet: Eric Trump said he recognized that his status as the president-elect’s son meant that donors to his foundation could try to use him to gain access to his father.
articles.abstract: Eric Trump said he recognized that his status as the president-elect’s son meant that donors to his foundation could try to use him to gain access to his father.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eric Trump said on Wednesday that he had decided to stop directly soliciting contributions for his charitable foundation, which supports causes like the fight against childhood cancer, because he now recognizes that his status as the president-elect’s son means that donors could try to use him to gain access to his father.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Bored, Broke and Armed: Clues to Chicago’s Gang Violence
articles.snippet: Gang members spend their days worrying about rivals and how to make money — and turn to shooting to settle even the pettiest disputes.
articles.abstract: Gang members spend their days worrying about rivals and how to make money — and turn to shooting to settle even the pettiest disputes.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The young men who call themselves Gangster Disciples skirted by an empty lot. They marched past a “Stop the Violence” mural painted on a corner store, coming to a halt when they saw members of a rival gang, the Black Disciples.

articles.headline: Alibaba Faces Growing Pressure Over Counterfeit Goods
articles.snippet: The United States put the Chinese company’s Taobao platform on a list of major markets for fakes, a move that Alibaba says may be politically motivated.
articles.abstract: The United States put the Chinese company’s Taobao platform on a list of major markets for fakes, a move that Alibaba says may be politically motivated.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Alibaba has a fakes problem.

articles.headline: Why the ‘Ghost Ship’ Was Invisible in Oakland, Until 36 Died
articles.snippet: The warehouse is close to a firehouse. Yet amid haphazard inspection protocols, it became the site of America’s worst structure fire in a decade.
articles.abstract: The warehouse is close to a firehouse. Yet amid haphazard inspection protocols, it became the site of America’s worst structure fire in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The charred, roofless shell of the Ghost Ship, the warehouse where 36 people perished on a chilly Friday evening in early December, is clearly visible from the driveway of Oakland firehouse No. 13.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Julie Turkewitz, Yamiche Alcindor, Conor Dougherty and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Automakers Prepare for an America That’s Over the Whole Car Thing
articles.snippet: Mobility services — ride hailing and other means of ferrying people to public transportation — look to be a lucrative and increasingly important sideline for carmakers.
articles.abstract: Mobility services — ride hailing and other means of ferrying people to public transportation — look to be a lucrative and increasingly important sideline for carmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, automakers have been able to count on a fundamental fact of American life: You pretty much need a car to get around.
